Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Tracking Long-Term Glacial-Interglacial Wind Pattern Variability in Central Asia Using Geochemical Analysis of Aerosol Derived Detritus
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a project to reconstruct the position of the winds, the patterns of the circulation and the source regions for the dust in central and eastern Asia during the Quaternary, the last 2.5 million years. The researchers will employ a novel technique of "fingerprinting" the chemical composition of the dust found in wind-derived sediments as well as in a variety of potential upstream source regions. The chemical characterization will be made using laser ablation mass spectrometry and the measurements will include U/Pb dating, trace metal measurements, and Hf (hafnium) isotope variability to determine source regions for the dust. The approach - using laser ablation mass spectrometry on individual zircon grains - is likely to provide unprecedented chemical information about the minerals and the rapid rate of sample analysis will produce strong a strong statistical basis for evaluating changes in grain chemistry and source region.

The broader impacts include: 1) application of a novel, new approach for characterizing the chemistry of the dust grains; 2) support for graduate students and undergraduates at two universities to participate in the research; 3) support for a new researcher embarking on an academic career; and 4) a strong element of international collaboration between the Institute of Tibetan Research in China and two universities in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the past 2.58 million years, Earth experienced alternating periods of colder temperatures when glaciers advanced (glacials) and warmer temperatures (interglacials). Knowing the extent to which Earth’s wind patterns varied between glacials and interglacials is critical for predicting how wind patterns will respond to future climate change.  Changes in the winds—past, present, and future—have and will continue to exert a profound influence on the distribution of precipitation, water resources, agricultural land, and human habitation.

 

Wind-transported material (dust) deposited during glacials and interglacials has potential to provide a record of past winds, if the source regions of the dust can be robustly identified. This NSF project enhanced our ability to efficiently determine accurate and precise formation ages of very small individual mineral grains in dust by using a laser-ablation system attached to a mass spectrometer. Past source-to-sink paths were reconstructed by comparing the ages of minerals in dust with those determined in potential dust-source regions.

 

The mineral dating technique was applied in central Asia because: 1) it hosts the Earth’s largest accumulation of glacial-interglacial dust (the Chinese Loess Plateau); 2) there is a debate about whether the dust sources have remained relatively static (located to north and northwest as in the modern climate) or were shifted significantly southward during glacials (located to the west and southwest); and 3) its potential dust-source regions are geologically diverse and thus distinguishable based on mineral age distributions. New data generated on samples collected from the dust deposits and inland desert source regions, together with compilation of published data by other researchers, yielded a statistically robust dataset. It was found that >50% of the minerals dated in glacial-aged dust can be attributed to sources to the west and southwest. This provides empirical evidence in favor of general circulation model simulations of glacial climate that show an equatorward shift in the mean position of the polar westerly jet streams. A corollary implication is that these westerly jet streams will shift poleward with continued global warming.

 

Another component of this project involved mapping wind-generated landforms in central Asia to better understand the near-surface wind patterns that dominate during wind storms and to identify regions that were likely contributors of large amounts of dust. This mapping resulted in the formulation of a new hypothesis about how the Chinese Loess Plateau was built and how it evolved in space and time. To the north and west of the Loess Plateau (in the modern upwind direction) is the Mu Us Desert, which is floored by bedrock and dune fields and lacks significant deposits of dust (loess). This project documented wind-eroded and wind-parallel linear landforms in the Mu Us Desert and on the Loess Plateau, and the downwind erosional retreat of the steep windward margin of the Loess Plateau. These observations suggest that the Mu Us Desert expanded during the past 2.6 million years as the windward margin of the Loess Plateau was sandblasted away and recycled farther downwind, similar to how a leaf blower generates a retreating vortex made of leaves and a growing pile of leaves downwind. This study showed how wind processes can simultaneously build and rework a loess plateau and recognized the Loess Plateau to not only be a sink, but also a source of dust throughout its evolution. A broader awareness of the latter may motivate wind-erosion mitigation and/or burn control efforts in the densely populated Loess Plateau region.
